//file: A list of random names, questions, and responses

answers.content: I beleive what you're looking for is an if statement. Please go read the documentation on this.
You can use the `square` function to draw a square with x, y and length

The `fill` function to change the color of your shapes. You can specify an set of rbg colors and set the color of the next shape you draw! For example, `fill(0); square(0, 0, 100)` draws a black square at 0, 0 with 100 height and width.
You can use the `for i in list` syntax

The `enumerate` function lets you loop through each index and value in an array, along with tuple destructuring. For example: `for index, value in ["hello", "world"]:
print(index, value)`
will print `0, "hello"
1, "world"`
That's because arrays and objects are always passed by reference, meaning a modification will be reflected to all references.
Processing will use integer division if the numerator is an integer. Therefore, you have to divide a float to get the answer you want. Try `3.0 / 10` or `float(myInt) / 10`.

```
which is printing out `['spam'] ['spam', 'spam'] ['spam', 'spam', 'spam']`
